alt_statements.statement: I think protecting the environment should come first, because this is the only planet we have and my generation has to live with the consequences. But I also know people need jobs and money to support their families, so I think we should focus on creating new kinds of work that are good for the earth, like clean energy and greener technology. If we make fair rules that help both nature and people, then we don’t have to choose between a healthy planet and a good life.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors watching birds, I see firsthand how fragile ecosystems are and how quickly habitats can vanish, so I believe environmental protection has to lead climate policy, not trail behind economic interests. That said, I work in retail and understand people need stable jobs, so the smart path is investing aggressively in clean energy and green infrastructure that create good-paying jobs while cutting emissions. We shouldn't accept the old idea that you have to wreck the environment to grow the economy—long-term prosperity depends on a stable climate and healthy natural world.

I think we should protect nature a lot because animals and people need clean air and water to live and be healthy. Grown‑ups should make rules so factories and businesses don’t hurt the earth too much, but they can still make things people need. If we use more clean energy and invent cool new things that don’t pollute, we can help both the planet and the economy at the same time.

As a moderate and a mom, I think we need climate policies that protect the environment without forgetting that families like mine depend on stable jobs and affordable energy. We should invest in practical, science-based solutions—like cleaner technologies and energy efficiency—that support long-term economic growth rather than stifle it. I don’t believe in extreme measures on either side; instead, we should aim for steady, realistic progress that preserves the planet for our kids while keeping communities and local businesses strong.

Given what I see in my work, I don’t buy the idea that environmental protection and economic growth are opposites—climate disasters are already incredibly expensive, and they’re only going to get worse if we don’t act. Climate policy should prioritize aggressive emissions reductions and resilience measures, even if that means short‑term costs, because the long‑term economic and human toll of inaction is far higher. The right balance is to set strong, science-based environmental standards and then give businesses clear, stable rules and incentives to innovate within that framework.

As a father and a provider with a stressful job tied to national security, I think climate policy has to protect the environment in a way that doesn’t cripple our economy or jeopardize American energy independence. We should invest in cleaner technologies and practical regulations, but always with an eye on jobs, cost of living, and keeping the U.S. from relying on foreign energy sources. Environmental goals need to be met through innovation, market incentives, and gradual transitions—not heavy-handed mandates that hit working families and businesses the hardest.

As someone who worked for years making sure a small, community-focused financial institution stayed healthy, I believe we need climate policies that protect God’s creation without strangling the jobs and savings that families depend on. We should focus on practical, market-based solutions and new technologies that reduce emissions over time, rather than heavy-handed regulations that hurt small businesses and rural communities. A strong economy gives us the resources to invest in cleaner energy and better stewardship, so the two goals ought to work together instead of being set against each other.

Como alguien que trabaja en telecomunicaciones y cree en la justicia social, pienso que no hay un verdadero crecimiento económico si se basa en destruir el medio ambiente, porque al final las comunidades más vulnerables —incluyendo muchas como la mía, migrante y de habla hispana— son las que pagan el precio primero. La política climática debe empujar con fuerza hacia energías limpias, eficiencia y transporte sostenible, pero hacerlo de forma planificada, con apoyo a los trabajadores y a las pequeñas empresas para que la transición verde genere empleos dignos en lugar de pérdidas. Desde mi fe, también siento una responsabilidad moral de ser “custodio” de la creación, así que para mí el equilibrio ideal es un modelo económico que mida el éxito no solo en dólares, sino en salud, dignidad y sostenibilidad para las próximas generaciones.

I think we should protect nature first, because if the air, water, and animals get too hurt, people can’t live good lives or have jobs anyway. Grown-ups should make rules so companies don’t pollute too much, but also help them use clean energy so they can still make money and parents can keep their jobs.

As a teacher and an avid gardener who sees firsthand how our local environment is changing, I believe climate policy has to treat environmental protection as the foundation of long-term economic growth, not as an obstacle to it. We should invest aggressively in clean energy, green infrastructure, and conservation, understanding that these create good jobs, protect public health, and preserve the natural world our kids—my students—will inherit. Economic growth that depletes resources and destabilizes the climate is a short-term illusion, so our policies should prioritize sustainability, equity, and scientific guidance even when that means asking businesses and consumers to adapt.

As someone who cares a lot about recycling and reducing waste, I don’t think we should see environmental protection and economic growth as enemies—climate policy should push us toward cleaner industries, green jobs, and sustainable technologies that actually create long-term prosperity. We can’t keep sacrificing the planet for short-term profit, especially when my generation will live with the consequences, so I support strong regulations on pollution and big investments in renewables, public transit, and energy efficiency.

Climate policy has to protect our land and communities, but it can’t cripple the economy or punish working families and small businesses in the process. I support reasonable, evidence-based environmental regulations that encourage innovation and cleaner technology, but I don’t believe in extreme measures that kill jobs, raise energy prices, or put us at a disadvantage against countries like China. The right balance is investing in practical solutions—like improving grid reliability, supporting nuclear and natural gas, and incentivizing businesses to cut emissions—without overregulating or growing government control.

As someone who works in business process improvement, I see environmental protection and economic growth as deeply intertwined rather than opposing goals. We should design climate policy that aggressively reduces emissions and protects ecosystems, but does so by incentivizing innovation, clean energy investment, and more efficient business practices. With smart regulations, clear carbon pricing, and strong public-private partnerships, we can transition to a low-carbon economy that actually creates high-quality jobs and long-term prosperity. As a Democrat and a Catholic, I also see this as a moral responsibility to care for creation and ensure a livable planet for future generations.

Como mujer mayor que ha trabajado toda la vida en un pequeño negocio, creo que debemos cuidar la creación de empleo y la economía, pero sin destruir la tierra que Dios nos dio. Para mí, la mejor política climática es la que protege el aire, el agua y la salud de nuestras familias, especialmente de los pobres, mientras apoya a los pequeños negocios y trabajadores para que puedan adaptarse sin arruinarse.

I think we need to protect the environment, but we have to be realistic about how new rules affect regular workers and small businesses. Climate policy should focus on practical steps like encouraging cleaner technology and American energy independence, not heavy-handed regulations that kill jobs or drive up prices for people who are already struggling.

As someone who spends most days in a hot kitchen and my free time hiking and watching birds, I feel strongly that we need to protect nature, but we must do it in a way that doesn’t crush small businesses and working people. Climate policies should encourage gradual, practical changes—like energy-efficient equipment and less waste in restaurants—supported by tax incentives and not heavy-handed regulations. We can care for the environment while still allowing the economy to grow, as long as the rules are realistic and give businesses time and help to adapt.

As someone who spent a career in banking and management, I believe we need a pragmatic, market-driven approach to climate policy that protects the environment without strangling economic growth. We should encourage innovation in cleaner technologies and support reasonable regulations that safeguard our air and water, but avoid heavy-handed mandates and new taxes that punish businesses and working families. A strong, growing economy gives us the resources to invest in environmental solutions, so the goal should be smart, balanced policies that keep American industry competitive while being good stewards of God’s creation.

As a Christian and a father, I believe we are called to be good stewards of God’s creation, but also to provide for our families and communities in a responsible way. Climate policy should protect the environment without crippling jobs, small businesses, or the ability of churches and charities to serve those in need. We should focus on practical, affordable solutions—like cleaner technologies, energy efficiency, and local conservation efforts—rather than sweeping regulations that hit working families the hardest. In all things, we must seek a balance that honors God’s creation while respecting the dignity of work and economic opportunity.

I’ve worked the land my whole life, and I know you can’t keep taking from the soil or the air without giving something back, or it’ll quit on you. That said, we can’t be shutting down farms, small businesses, and energy jobs in the name of climate policy cooked up by folks who never got dirt under their nails. We need practical, affordable steps that cut waste and pollution—like better equipment, smarter water use, and sensible energy improvements—without strangling the rural economy or driving up costs for people on fixed incomes. Protect God’s creation, yes, but do it in a way that keeps food on the table and towns alive.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because it’s our future and my generation will be the ones stuck living with the damage if we don’t act now. At the same time, I get that people need jobs and money to live, so climate policies should push for cleaner technologies and new kinds of work instead of just shutting things down overnight. If we invest in green energy and better public transit, we can help the planet and still keep the economy growing, just in a different, more responsible way.

I think we’ve got to protect the environment because it’s the only one we’ve got, but we also have to be realistic about people needing steady work to support their families. Climate policies should push companies toward cleaner practices and new technologies, but in a way that doesn’t suddenly shut down factories or wipe out whole communities. I’d like to see more investment in cleaner equipment and energy for existing industries, so folks like me can keep working while we gradually cut pollution. That seems like a fair balance between responsibility to the planet and responsibility to working people.

I think we’ve got to be smart about climate policy so it protects the land and air we all depend on, without crushing the folks who actually keep the economy moving. As a truck driver, I see how regulations can pile up costs on working people, so I’d rather see incentives for cleaner technology and practical standards than heavy-handed rules from Washington. We should push for innovation—more efficient trucks, better fuels, smarter logistics—so businesses can grow and jobs stay strong while we still take care of God’s creation.

As someone who works hard to support my family and wants a healthy planet for my kids, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as enemies—we need both, but we can’t keep delaying serious action on climate. The government should invest in clean energy, green jobs, and public transit so that working families like mine aren’t the ones paying the highest price for pollution and extreme weather. Businesses should be held to strong environmental standards, and there should be support to help workers and small companies transition, instead of just letting big corporations off the hook.

Coming from North Carolina and working campus security, I see firsthand how extreme heat and storms can disrupt students’ lives and the local economy, so I don’t buy the idea that we have to choose between the environment and jobs. A smart climate policy should invest in clean energy, public transit, and building upgrades in ways that create stable, good-paying work, especially for Black communities that have been hit hardest by pollution and inequality. As a progressive and a Christian, I feel we have a moral duty to be good stewards of creation while making sure the clean-energy transition doesn’t leave working people behind.

I think we need to protect our air and water, but we can’t do it in a way that crushes jobs and raises costs so much that folks on fixed incomes can’t afford to get by. Climate policies should focus on practical steps—like cleaner technology in factories and incentives for businesses to improve—without strangling American industry with red tape. I’d rather see gradual, realistic changes that keep our economy strong than sweeping measures that sound good on paper but hurt workers and manufacturers.

I think we need to protect the environment, but we can’t ignore how much families like mine depend on affordable energy and steady jobs. Climate policies should focus on practical steps—like encouraging cleaner technologies and American-made energy—without crushing small businesses or driving up prices at the grocery store and gas pump. We should move toward cleaner options, but in a gradual, realistic way that keeps our economy strong and doesn’t leave working people behind.

As someone who makes a living in tech and cares about innovation, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—in the long run, a stable climate is a prerequisite for a stable economy. We should invest aggressively in clean energy, modern infrastructure, and green tech, using market incentives and strong regulations to push businesses toward sustainability without killing opportunity. I’d rather see us lead in building the next generation of climate-friendly technologies than cling to outdated industries that put both our health and our future at risk.

I believe we have a duty to be good stewards of God’s creation, but we also have to use common sense so we don’t cripple our economy or burden working families and retirees on fixed incomes. Climate policies should focus on practical, cost‑effective steps—like improving energy efficiency, supporting cleaner technology, and encouraging innovation in the private sector—without heavy-handed regulations that kill jobs or drive up energy prices. The right balance is protecting the environment while keeping America strong, competitive, and affordable for ordinary citizens.

I believe we’re called to be good stewards of God’s creation, but we also need to protect the ability of families and churches to make a living. Climate policies should focus on practical, common-sense steps—like encouraging cleaner technology, energy efficiency, and responsible use of resources—without crushing small businesses or driving up costs for ordinary people. We should aim for gradual, realistic improvements that respect both the environment and the livelihoods that depend on a strong economy.

Where I live, the land and animals are really important, and my family always says we have to take care of what God made so it’s still here for the kids who come after us. I think we should protect the earth first and then find smart ways to make money that don’t hurt it so much, like clean energy and jobs that help nature instead of breaking it.

As someone who’s seen my Florida community weather hurricanes and rising heat, I believe strong environmental protection isn’t a luxury, it’s a necessity for our long‑term economic health. We can and should invest in clean energy, resilient infrastructure, and conservation in ways that create good jobs and protect working families, rather than pitting the environment against the economy. For me, caring for creation is a moral responsibility, and good climate policy should prioritize people’s well‑being—especially our children’s future—over short‑term corporate profits.

As someone who worked hard my whole life in construction and lives on a modest retirement, I believe climate policy has to protect both God’s creation and people’s ability to make an honest living. We should invest in cleaner technologies and energy sources, but do it in a way that doesn’t crush small businesses, raise bills too high for working families and seniors, or wipe out good jobs. I trust more in local communities, private innovation, and common‑sense regulations than in heavy-handed federal mandates that can hurt the economy. Environmental protection is important, but it needs to be balanced with practical policies that keep America strong and working people secure.

I think we have to stop acting like protecting the environment and growing the economy are opposite goals—they’re tied together, especially for people like me who depend on tourism and travel for work. Climate policy should push businesses to go greener with incentives and clear rules, but not in a way that suddenly kills jobs or makes basic things unaffordable. If we invest in cleaner energy and smarter infrastructure, we can create new kinds of work and keep places people want to visit beautiful and livable. For me, the right balance is firm long-term environmental commitments with flexible, realistic steps that help workers and businesses adapt instead of just punishing them.

As someone who works in science and is immersed in technology, I think the supposed trade-off between environmental protection and economic growth is often overstated—long-term economic stability depends on a livable planet. Climate policy should aggressively cut emissions and protect ecosystems, while channeling public investment into clean energy, research, and green infrastructure that can drive innovation, create skilled jobs, and reduce inequality. From a progressive and faith-informed perspective, we have a moral responsibility to steward creation responsibly, which means prioritizing sustainability even if it requires short-term economic adjustments.

As a young mom and someone who cares a lot about my comunidad and our future, I don’t think we can treat environmental protection and economic growth like they’re enemies. We should be investing in clean energy, green jobs, and better public transit so people—especially workers and families—can have good-paying trabajos without wrecking the climate my child will grow up in. Strong climate policy should put frontline communities and workers first, helping them transition instead of leaving them behind. In the long run, a healthy planet is the foundation of any real, sustainable economic growth.

I think we should take care of the earth first, because it’s our home that God made and we have to share it with other kids and animals. Grown‑ups can still make money and build things, but they should do it in ways that don’t make the air dirty or hurt places where people like me live and play. If we protect nature now, we can all have good jobs and a safe, clean world when I get bigger.

I think climate policy should put protecting the environment first, because my generation is the one that’s going to live with the consequences, but it also has to respect that people need jobs and affordable basics like food and energy. We should invest in clean energy, public transit, and greener tech so that new kinds of jobs are created instead of just shutting stuff down and leaving communities behind.

As someone who’s lived long enough to see how polluted rivers can become clean again and how jobs can disappear when we don’t plan ahead, I don’t think we should treat environmental protection and economic growth as opposites. We should invest heavily in clean energy, conservation, and green infrastructure, creating stable, good-paying jobs while preserving the climate for our grandchildren and the natural world I cherish in my garden. If we insist on short-term profits over long-term sustainability, we’ll end up paying far more—economically, morally, and spiritually—down the line.

I believe climate policy has to protect the environment without crippling the industries and transportation systems that keep this country running. We should invest in practical, proven technologies that reduce emissions over time, while preserving jobs, keeping energy affordable, and maintaining strong infrastructure. Heavy-handed regulations that hurt workers and drive businesses overseas do more harm than good, both economically and environmentally. A realistic, gradual approach that encourages innovation and efficiency—not mandates and shutdowns—is the right balance.

At my age, I’ve seen how much our communities depend both on a healthy environment and on people having steady work, so I don’t think we can afford to treat those as opposing goals. Climate policy should encourage businesses and towns to shift toward cleaner energy and conservation in a gradual, practical way, with support for workers and small communities so they’re not left behind. We have a responsibility, as stewards of God’s creation, to reduce pollution and protect the world our grandchildren will inherit, but we need to do it with common sense, listening to scientists and also to the people whose livelihoods are affected.

I think we should take care of the Earth even if it costs a lot of money, because this is the only home God gave us and I want it to be safe when I grow up. Grown‑ups should still make sure people can have jobs and take care of their families, but they shouldn’t choose money if it hurts the air, water, and animals too much.

As someone who immigrated from the Philippines and now works in accounting, I see every day how economic stability matters for families like mine—but I also know that without a livable climate, no balance sheet truly adds up. Climate policy should treat environmental protection as a non‑negotiable foundation and then drive economic growth through clean energy, resilient infrastructure, and green jobs, especially for working people and vulnerable communities. We shouldn’t accept the old tradeoff of “jobs versus the planet”; smart regulations and incentives can push businesses to innovate while ensuring that those most affected by climate change and the transition—both here and abroad—are supported.

I think protecting the environment should come first, because if we ruin the planet now, there won’t be a safe place for me, my little brothers, or future kids to live and work. But I also know my parents work hard and worry about money, so climate policies should help create good jobs in clean energy and not make it harder for families like mine to pay for things they need.

I think we need a climate policy that protects the environment without killing the very jobs and businesses that keep our communities alive. I work in building materials, and I see firsthand how higher costs and regulations hit working folks and small contractors, not just big corporations. We should invest in cleaner technologies, energy efficiency, and responsible resource use, but do it in a way that encourages innovation and growth instead of top‑down mandates that punish the economy. God gave us this earth to steward wisely, and that includes both caring for nature and making sure people can work, build, and provide for themselves.

As a physician and immigrant who has seen how environmental degradation worsens human suffering, I believe climate policy must treat environmental protection as the non‑negotiable foundation on which sustainable economic growth is built, not a competing goal. In practical terms, that means strong emissions limits and investment in clean technologies, combined with policies that ease the transition for workers and businesses. My Catholic and humanistic values push me to prioritize the health and dignity of current and future generations over short‑term profit, but my liberal outlook also favors innovation and market incentives to drive this change efficiently. A healthy economy ultimately depends on a healthy planet, so any “balance” that sacrifices the latter is both ethically wrong and economically shortsighted.

As a mom, a Catholic, and someone who makes a living in a tech-related industry, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we should be investing in cleaner technologies and energy so we create good jobs while safeguarding the planet our kids will inherit. Government has a real role to play in setting strong standards and offering incentives that push businesses to innovate, not just cut corners. If we’re smart about it, climate policy can support working families like mine by driving new industries, keeping communities healthy, and making sure no one gets left behind in the transition.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because once nature is destroyed, we can’t really get it back, and people like my family who don’t have a lot of money will be hurt the most by floods, heat, and storms. But I also know families need jobs, so climate policies should help create new kinds of work, like in clean energy and sustainable farming, instead of just shutting things down. If governments and companies really cared, they’d invest in green jobs and better public transport so the economy can grow without ruining the planet. For me, “economic growth” only makes sense if it doesn’t sacrifice the future environment my generation will live in.

As someone who drives for a living and sees the city’s smog and traffic up close every day, I think it’s obvious we can’t keep treating the environment as an afterthought to growth. We need strong climate policies that aggressively push clean energy and public transit, but they should also support workers and small businesses through the transition—grants for cleaner vehicles, better infrastructure, and retraining where needed. Environmental protection and economic growth don’t have to be enemies if we’re willing to invest smartly and make the long-term health of people and the planet the priority.

As someone who works in the restaurant industry and depends on steady business to support my family, I think we can’t ignore the economy when we talk about climate policy—but we also can’t pretend the environment is separate from it. If climate change hurts our food supply, raises prices, or makes energy costs unpredictable, that hits working people and small businesses first. I’d like to see policies that push cleaner energy and more sustainable practices, but phased in with support for workers and businesses so people aren’t crushed in the process. For me, the right balance is protecting the environment in a way that keeps opportunity and economic mobility open for regular families like mine.

As a working mom and primary breadwinner, I believe climate policy has to protect both the environment my kids will inherit and the jobs that keep our family secure. We should pursue practical, market-driven solutions—like encouraging innovation in cleaner energy and efficiency—rather than heavy-handed regulations that punish businesses and drive up costs. A healthy economy gives us the resources to invest in conservation and protect the natural places my family loves, so environmental goals and economic growth need to move forward together, not in opposition.

I think climate policy should put environmental protection first, because if we wreck the planet now, there won’t even be an economy for my generation later. At the same time, we should invest in green jobs and clean energy so people can still work and support their families while we transition away from fossil fuels. It shouldn’t be about choosing between the environment and growth, but about redefining growth so it doesn’t depend on pollution.

As someone who works in real estate and cares deeply about both my community and the environment, I believe climate policy has to protect our natural resources without strangling economic opportunity. We should prioritize market-based solutions, innovation, and incentives for cleaner technologies rather than heavy-handed regulation that drives up costs for businesses and homeowners. Strong, stable economic growth gives us the means to invest in resilience and cleaner infrastructure, so the goal should be policies that make it easier—not harder—for American workers and companies to adapt and lead in a lower-emissions future.

As someone who’s built a good life for my family through the music industry, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need policies that push clean innovation so people can still work, create, and provide. Climate change hits Black communities and working families hard, so we can’t just chase short-term profits and pretend it’s not our problem. I want climate policy that invests in green jobs, cleaner cities, and resilient infrastructure, so my kids can grow up breathing cleaner air while still having real opportunities to thrive.

As someone who works in manufacturing and cares deeply about both my community and the environment, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need policies that push companies to innovate cleaner processes rather than just slow production. Climate policy should set strong, science-based limits on pollution and invest in green technology and worker retraining so that people like me can keep stable jobs while our industries become more sustainable.

I think we need a climate policy that protects our air, water, and land without destroying the jobs and industries that keep working people like me afloat. We should focus on practical steps—like making cars and factories more efficient, investing in cleaner technology, and encouraging American-made innovation—rather than heavy-handed regulations that push companies and jobs overseas. Environmental protection matters, but it has to be done in a way that keeps our economy strong and our manufacturing base here at home.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when we treat the environment as expendable in the name of “growth,” and it’s usually ordinary people and future generations who pay the price. We need climate policies that put environmental protection first and then design economic growth around that—investing in clean energy, green jobs, and infrastructure that’s both sustainable and fair. Short-term profits for a few shouldn’t outweigh a livable planet, especially when we have the tools to transition to a cleaner economy without leaving workers and communities behind.

As a nurse and a woman of faith, I believe we have a moral duty to protect the environment because it is directly tied to our patients’ health, especially in vulnerable communities like many Black and immigrant neighborhoods that already bear the brunt of pollution. Climate policy should put environmental protection first, but it doesn’t have to come at the expense of economic growth—it should drive a new kind of growth through clean energy jobs, healthier workplaces, and investments in resilient communities. We need strong regulations on emissions and pollution, paired with support for workers and businesses to transition, so that we are not choosing between a paycheck today and our children’s livable future tomorrow.

As a conservative, a father, and someone who works every day to keep our communities safe and functioning, I believe climate policy has to protect both our environment and our livelihoods. We should focus on practical, cost‑effective measures—like improving energy efficiency, supporting responsible domestic energy production, and encouraging innovation—rather than sweeping regulations that hurt working families and strain local budgets. Economic growth is what funds better infrastructure, emergency services, and conservation efforts, so the goal should be smart stewardship of our resources, not policies that punish growth.

I think we should protect nature first, because if we ruin the planet, there won’t be a safe place for people or businesses anyway. Grown-ups should use money and inventions to make cleaner energy and less pollution, even if it costs more at the start, so that kids like me can still have forests, animals, and fresh air when we’re older.

I think we should protect nature first, because this is the only planet we have and I want it to still be beautiful and safe when I grow up. Grown-ups can make new kinds of jobs and businesses that don’t hurt the air and water so much, like using more sun and wind instead of things that make smoke. If people work together and share money fairly, families can still have what they need while we keep animals, trees, and the weather from getting worse.

Given what we know today, I don’t really see environmental protection and economic growth as opposing forces anymore; the real economic risk is failing to act on climate. Smart climate policy should push hard on decarbonization—through clean energy, efficiency, and innovation—while cushioning workers and communities that are most affected by the transition. As someone who works in tech and does well financially, I think higher-income people and profitable companies should shoulder more of the cost, because the long-term benefits—a stable climate, cleaner air, and new industries—far outweigh the short-term trade-offs.

As someone who’s young, active, and planning for a long future on this planet, I think protecting the environment has to come first, and our economic growth should adapt around that reality. Climate change is already hitting vulnerable people hardest, and it’s unfair and short-sighted to treat the planet like it’s disposable just to boost short-term profits. That said, we should use this transition to create new green jobs and industries, so it’s not “environment vs. economy” but a different kind of economy that’s cleaner, fairer, and more sustainable.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when we put off hard choices, and with the climate, delay only makes things costlier for our communities and our grandchildren’s future. I believe environmental protection has to lead the way, but we should pair strong climate rules with support for workers and small businesses so the transition to clean energy creates good jobs instead of leaving folks behind.

I think we should protect the Earth first, because if the air and water get ruined, people and animals can’t live healthy lives or have good jobs anyway. Grown‑ups should still try to make money and build cool things, but they should do it in ways that don’t hurt the planet so much, like using cleaner energy and not wasting stuff.

As someone who works in early childhood education and is raising young kids, I see climate policy as a moral responsibility to protect their future, not just a line item in an economic report. We should prioritize strong environmental protections and a rapid transition to clean energy, but do it in a way that creates good jobs, supports working families, and invests in communities that might be hurt by the shift. Economic growth that destroys the planet our children will inherit isn’t real progress, so climate policy should treat sustainability as the foundation of long-term prosperity, not a trade-off.

I think we should protect nature a lot, because animals and trees can’t fix things if we break them, but people can still find new ways to make money that don’t hurt the Earth so much. Grown‑ups should spend more money and time on clean energy and safer factories, even if it’s a little harder at first, because we’re the ones who have to live here when we grow up.

As someone who’s lived long enough to see the climate change in my own backyard, I think we can’t keep treating environmental protection as optional or secondary to economic growth. A healthy economy ultimately depends on a healthy planet, so our policies should prioritize rapid emissions reductions and clean energy, while supporting workers and communities through the transition. We should invest heavily in green jobs, infrastructure, and research, and accept that short-term costs are worth it to avoid far greater human and economic losses down the line.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when we ignore pollution and the environment, and I don’t want my grand-nieces and nephews growing up in a world that’s burning or flooding just so a few companies can keep their profits up. I think we need strong climate rules that put people’s health and the planet first, and then help workers and small businesses adapt with things like job training and clean-energy investments. Economic growth that destroys our air, water, and weather isn’t really “growth” at all—it’s a bill our kids will have to pay.

As a dad and a software developer at a public university, I see climate policy as an investment in my kids’ future and in long-term economic stability, not a drag on growth. We should prioritize strong environmental protections while driving innovation—things like clean energy research, green infrastructure, and retraining programs—so that workers and families aren’t left behind. Economic growth that’s built on burning out our planet is fake prosperity; smart climate policy should aim for jobs, health, and sustainability at the same time.

I think we need to protect the environment, but we can’t do it in a way that wipes out good-paying jobs for working folks, especially in manufacturing. Climate rules should be practical, gradual, and focused on innovation—like cleaner tech and more efficient processes—so companies can stay competitive and people like me can keep a steady job. Government shouldn’t be picking winners and losers, but it can set reasonable standards and then let businesses figure out how to meet them without crippling the economy.

As someone who works every day with families who are already struggling, I can’t accept a climate policy that treats environmental protection and economic security as if they’re in conflict. We need strong climate action that creates good, dignified jobs—especially in frontline and low-income communities—so people aren’t forced to choose between a paycheck and a livable planet. For me, justice means holding polluters accountable, investing in clean energy and public transit, and making sure the costs of transition don’t fall on those who’ve had the least and suffered the most. That’s the balance: economic growth that is measured not just in profit, but in health, opportunity, and fairness for everyone.

As a mom, a teacher, and someone who wants my kids to grow up with clean air and safe weather, I think climate policy has to put environmental protection first, but in a way that supports working families and creates good jobs. We shouldn’t accept the idea that we have to choose between a healthy planet and a strong economy—investing in renewable energy, green infrastructure, and energy‑efficient schools can create stable, middle‑class jobs while cutting pollution. Environmental rollbacks that boost short‑term profits but harm children’s health and future are not worth it, especially when we have the technology and resources to grow our economy sustainably.

As a husband, dad, and teacher, I want my kids to grow up with clean air and water, but I also know families like mine depend on stable jobs and affordable energy. Climate policy should focus on practical, market-based solutions—like supporting cleaner technologies, improving energy efficiency, and encouraging responsible innovation—without crushing small businesses or driving up costs for working families. We need to protect the environment, but we have to do it in a way that keeps our economy strong, our communities stable, and our freedoms intact.

As a teacher and someone who spends a lot of time outdoors bird-watching and hiking, I feel strongly that environmental protection has to be a central, non-negotiable pillar of climate policy, not an afterthought to economic growth. That said, I don’t see these goals as mutually exclusive—if we invest in green technologies, sustainable infrastructure, and environmental education, we can create good jobs while preserving the natural world my students and I depend on. I support policies that ask more of large polluters and provide support for workers and communities during the transition, so economic growth is cleaner, fairer, and truly long-term.

Working in higher education and health, I see firsthand how environmental degradation ultimately harms people’s well-being, especially the most vulnerable, so I believe strong environmental protection has to be the foundation of any long-term economic growth. We shouldn’t treat it as a zero-sum game; investing in clean energy, resilient infrastructure, and green jobs can create healthier communities and sustainable prosperity. As a liberal and a nurse, I’d rather we err on the side of caution and public health, even if that means short-term tradeoffs for certain industries, because the costs of inaction will be far greater for future generations.

As someone who works for myself and is raising kids, I think climate policy has to protect both the planet and working families at the same time. We can’t ignore environmental damage, because my kids and our community will live with those consequences, but we also can’t pass laws that crush small businesses and workers. The right balance is investing in clean energy, green jobs, and support for small shops and low-income neighborhoods so that going green actually creates opportunity instead of taking it away.

As a mom and a working professional, I don’t buy the idea that we have to choose between a healthy planet and a healthy economy—long-term economic growth depends on not wrecking the environment my kids will grow up in. Climate policy should aggressively cut emissions and invest in clean energy and infrastructure, while providing real support and retraining for workers and communities that depend on fossil fuel industries. Environmental protections shouldn’t be gutted for short-term profit, but they should be designed in a practical, business-friendly way so companies can adapt and innovate rather than just relocate or shut down.

I work in pest control and see every day how important a clean, safe environment is, but I also know that if businesses can’t afford to operate, people like me lose our jobs. Climate policy should push for practical, affordable steps—like improving energy efficiency and encouraging cleaner tech—without crushing small companies and driving up costs for working families. We ought to protect God’s creation, but in a way that respects hard work, economic growth, and doesn’t leave regular folks paying the price for decisions made far away from our day-to-day reality.

I like when we plant trees and keep the air clean so we can play outside and not get sick. Grown-ups should make money and have jobs, but they shouldn’t break the world God made for us. I think we should use smart ideas and new things so we can have both good jobs and a safe place to live.

I think we should take care of the Earth first, because if the air and water get too dirty, people and animals can’t be healthy or happy. Grown-ups should make new kinds of jobs and machines that don’t hurt the planet so much, so people can still earn money while we keep nature safe.

As someone who’s spent his career running a business in a very practical, nuts-and-bolts industry, I believe we need climate policies that protect God’s creation without crippling the jobs and communities that depend on steady economic growth. We should encourage innovation, cleaner technologies, and energy efficiency through market incentives and common-sense regulation, not blanket mandates that drive costs up for small companies and working families. The right balance is protecting the environment while keeping America competitive and strong, so we can pass on both a healthy economy and a healthy planet to the next generation.

As someone in the military and a parent, I see climate policy as a national security and family issue, not just an environmental one. We should push for practical measures that cut emissions and protect our land and water, but they must not cripple economic growth, defense readiness, or working families’ livelihoods. I support investing in cleaner technologies, resilient infrastructure, and energy independence so we’re stronger economically and strategically, rather than relying on heavy-handed regulations that don’t account for real-world costs.

As someone trained to think in terms of trade-offs and long-term optimization, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposing variables so much as tightly coupled ones—unchecked climate damage is simply a deferred economic cost with interest. Climate policy should set firm, science-based constraints on emissions and ecosystem damage, and then let innovation and market mechanisms operate within those bounds to drive growth. In practice, that means aggressive decarbonization, strong regulation of pollution, and large-scale investment in clean energy and green infrastructure, with special attention to supporting workers and communities through the transition.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors hiking, I feel like protecting the environment has to come first, because once we wreck our climate and ecosystems, you can’t really buy them back with economic growth. That said, I don’t think it’s “environment versus jobs” if we’re smart about it—climate policy should push for cleaner tech, better public transit, and green jobs so people like me who work regular service and driving gigs don’t get left behind.

We need to protect the environment, but we can’t do it in a way that crushes working folks and small towns that depend on jobs and affordable energy. I think climate policy should focus on practical, gradual improvements—supporting cleaner technology, nuclear power, and conservation—without heavy-handed regulations that kill businesses or drive up costs for people on fixed incomes like me. We should encourage American innovation and self-reliance, not punish it, and make sure any changes are tested, reasonable, and don’t put our economy or our freedoms at risk.

As someone who has lived long enough to see the climate change around me, I believe protecting the environment has to come first, even if it means slowing certain kinds of economic growth. Any “growth” that destroys the planet we’re leaving to future generations isn’t real progress; it’s just borrowing against their well‑being. That said, I think we can and should create jobs and new industries through clean energy and conservation, so that working people aren’t left behind as we transition to a more sustainable economy.

As someone who spent her career in environmental science, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites, but I do believe the environment has to set the boundaries within which the economy operates. Climate policy should prioritize rapid emissions reductions and ecosystem protection, while investing in clean energy, public health, and green jobs that create sustainable growth over the long term. We’ve already pushed natural systems close to their limits; any “growth” that depends on degrading air, water, and climate isn’t real prosperity, it’s borrowing against our grandchildren’s future.

As someone who manages IT projects and thinks a lot about long-term planning, I see climate policy the same way I see a critical infrastructure upgrade: you invest up front, or you pay much more later in failures and downtime. We shouldn’t frame environmental protection and economic growth as opposing goals—strong, science-based climate standards can actually drive innovation, create high-quality jobs in clean tech, and make our economy more resilient for our kids’ generation. I support policies that aggressively cut emissions and incentivize green technologies while providing real transition support for workers and businesses, especially in legacy industries. That’s the balance: firm environmental guardrails, pro-growth investment in clean innovation, and a just transition so people aren’t left behind.

Como alguien que trabaja en la construcción y vive de los proyectos que se levantan cada año, creo que necesitamos una política climática que proteja el medio ambiente sin dejar a los trabajadores atrás. Hay formas de crecer económicamente con normas más verdes: mejor aislamiento, materiales más eficientes, energía solar en las obras, transporte más limpio; eso crea empleo y cuida la tierra al mismo tiempo. El problema es cuando el costo de las nuevas reglas cae sólo sobre los pequeños negocios y los trabajadores inmigrantes, mientras las grandes empresas contaminan y siguen ganando. Para mí, el equilibrio es exigir fuerte protección ambiental, pero con apoyo económico, capacitación y programas especiales para que los trabajadores y los pequeños contratistas podamos adaptarnos y prosperar en esa transición.

As a teacher, a mom, and an immigrant who’s seen both poverty and opportunity up close, I don’t think we can treat environmental protection and economic growth as opposite goals anymore. We need climate policies that aggressively cut emissions, protect vulnerable communities, and invest in green jobs and public education, so working families and their kids aren’t left behind. True growth today means clean air, secure jobs in sustainable industries, and a livable planet for our students and our own children.

We absolutely need to be good stewards of God’s creation, but we also have to use common sense so we don’t cripple our economy or hurt working families and retirees on fixed incomes. Climate policy should focus on practical steps—like encouraging cleaner technology, conservation, and responsible industry—without heavy-handed regulations or sudden changes that drive up energy costs and destroy jobs.

I like when we plant trees and keep the air clean, because my mom says God made the world and we’re supposed to take care of it. Grown‑ups should make rules so we don’t hurt animals and the sky, but also so people can still have jobs and money to buy food and toys.

As a nurse, I see every day how a healthy environment is directly tied to people’s health, especially for vulnerable patients and working families. I believe we must prioritize strong environmental protections while using smart, science-based policies and investments to create good jobs and guide economic growth in a cleaner direction. We shouldn’t accept the idea that we have to sacrifice our children’s future or working people’s livelihoods—good climate policy can and should do both: protect creation and strengthen the economy.

Como alguien que vive modestamente, trabaja en el comercio y ve lo difícil que es para muchos llegar a fin de mes, creo que la política climática tiene que proteger el medio ambiente sin olvidar a los trabajadores y los negocios pequeños. Para mí, el equilibrio está en invertir fuerte en energías limpias, transporte público y eficiencia energética, de manera que se creen buenos empleos y se bajen costos a largo plazo, en lugar de simplemente imponer reglas que encarezcan todo de golpe. Además, las comunidades trabajadoras y latinas, como la mía, deben ser prioridad en esos planes, recibiendo apoyo para capacitación, adaptación y acceso a nuevas oportunidades económicas verdes.

I think we should protect nature a lot because it’s like taking care of the world God gave us, and we want animals, trees, and people to stay safe and healthy. Grown‑ups and companies should still be able to make money and have jobs, but they should do it in ways that don’t hurt the air and water so much, like using cleaner energy and not wasting things.

I think we need a climate policy that protects our land, air, and water without strangling the businesses and workers that keep our communities running. Smart, market-based solutions and innovation—like cleaner tech and more efficient energy use—make more sense to me than heavy-handed regulations that kill jobs and raise costs. We should focus on policies that help American workers and companies lead in cleaner production, not ship jobs overseas to places with weaker standards.

As someone who teaches at a public university and spends a fair amount of time watching bird populations shift with the seasons, I see climate policy as an investment in the ecological systems that underpin long-term economic well-being. We should prioritize strong environmental protections—even at the cost of short-term economic disruption—while using smart policy tools (like carbon pricing, green industrial policy, and just-transition programs) to direct economic growth toward low-carbon sectors. In the long run, an economy that degrades climate stability and biodiversity is eroding its own productive base, so “growth” that ignores planetary limits is neither sustainable nor genuinely prosperous.

Working in manufacturing and raising kids, I see both sides: we need solid jobs and a healthy planet for our children to grow up in. I think climate policy should push companies, including auto and parts makers like where I work, to adopt cleaner tech and more efficient processes, but with practical timelines and support so workers aren’t left behind. If we invest in green innovation—better batteries, smarter factories, cleaner materials—we can protect the environment while creating more stable, higher-quality jobs. For me, economic growth and environmental protection should be treated as partners, not trade-offs.

I spent a career keeping the lights on and I know firsthand that you don’t just flip a switch and walk away from the grid or the jobs it supports. We’ve got to protect the environment because there’s no economy on a dead planet, but we also need practical, step-by-step policies that keep power reliable and affordable while we transition to cleaner sources. I support investing in modern, resilient infrastructure and cleaner technologies, as long as we do it in a way that doesn’t abandon workers or communities that have depended on traditional energy for generations.

We need to be good stewards of God’s creation, but we also have to live in the real world where people need steady work and affordable energy. Climate policies should focus on practical measures—like cleaner technology, better fuel efficiency, and sensible regulations—that reduce pollution without killing jobs or driving small businesses and working families into the ground.
